title: The one dish you must try
text:
Who does the best dumplings in Hong Kong? It’s a hard pick. Source: Supplied 
IT’S the famous city of skyscrapers, with a buzzing night-life and an even bigger food scene. 
Hong Kong is a city that loves to eat with more than 12,000 restaurants packed into the tiny territory. 
As one of the most densely populated places on Earth it has earnt its reputation as the culinary capital of Asia. But the traditional food scene in Hong Kong is changing. A new wave of foreign chefs have entered the market bringing with them bold concepts that experiment with traditional Chinese dishes. 
Think Yunan style steak tartare, or prawn toast piled high with shaved cabbage and mayonnaise. This fusion of Eastern and Western influences is having a dramatic impact on the dining scene as chefs compete to bring something new to the market. The traditional food scene in Hong Kong is changing. Source: Supplied A twist on the classic prawn toast at Ho Lee Fook. Source: Supplied 
Gone are the typical bright lights and plastic table cloths and in are moodily lit underground spaces with no expense spared on decor. 
Open plan kitchens, carefully crafted cocktails and a trend towards fusion plates intricately presented has hit the menus. 
Neil Perry, one of Australia’s most influential chefs and restaurateurs has a special interest in the Hong Kong movement. 
His Rockpool Group empire has eight restaurants under its banner as well as being the consulting group for Qantas’ in-flight and lounge menus, and most recently the airline’s wine list. 
Perry’s inspiration for Asian dining is obvious. His restaurant, Spice Temple, in Sydney and Melbourne represents everything he loves about the intricate Asian cuisine. 
For the last 20 years Perry has visited Hong Kong at least annually looking for inspiration, new flavours and styles for the Qantas menus and his Rockpool Group. Yung Kee is famous for its traditional roast goose dish. Source: Supplied 
“My favourite restaurants are Asian — Japanese, Korean, Thai and of course Chinese. Having two Chinese restaurants there’s no better place for me to come for inspiration than Hong Kong. Every time I’m here I walk away with a new inspiration for a dish or just a new amount of energy. I love the passion of Chinese cooking,” he says. 
Like the restaurant scene, Perry says that the way you shop for produce in Hong Kong is changing too. The 160 year old Graham Street wet market where you’ll find stalls of fresh fruit, vegetables, meat and seafood, has been drastically reduced to a few winding streets, a victim of the prime real estate it sits on. 
“In about five years time they won’t be exist” Perry said. “Sadly, they’re being reclaimed for luxury housing and so if you’re visiting they are an absolute must-see. A slice of old Hong Kong and a glimpse into local cuisine”. The wet markets are slowly disappearing from central Hong Kong. Source: Supplied 
However despite this new wave of dining, a place for traditional Chinese restaurants will always remain. The famous classic dishes such as Peking duck, barbecue suckling pig and roast goose will always be synonymous with Chinese cooking. But what’s interesting to see is the modern twist being applied to these recipes. 
Here are six restaurants, both traditional and modern, defining Hong Kong’s dining scene. 
Lung King Heen , Four Seasons Hotel 
Hong Kong’s only Michelin three starred restaurant, dining at the Four Season Hotel is nothing but incredibly special. “It is the best yum cha in the world,” says Perry who points out the lightest of pastries and the most delicate dumplings. 
Their signature steamed shrimp and crabmeat dumpling (the world’s best dumpling) is served in its own basket and comes topped with a gold leaf and it’s the one dish you must try. 
The chicken and truffle spring roll with its delicate crisp pastry is also a standout. The world’s best dumpling is found at Lung King Heen. Source: Supplied 
Ho Lee Fook 
One of the latest restaurants in a string of hipster Chinese restaurants on Hong Kong island, the cheekily named Ho Lee Fook is the brains of Sydney chef Jowett Yu — formerly of Mr Wong and Ms G’s. 
His fusion of traditional Chinese recipes with a modern twist include drunken clams in beer and Shaoxing and roast wagyu short ribs. 
Spring Moon , Peninsula Hotel 
The Peninsula Hotel’s famous Cantonese restaurant has for many years been one of Hong Kong’s best restaurants. 
“The yum cha is legendary,” says Perry — the Peninsula’s dim sum kitchen is one of the most revered in the world. Spring Moon is also thought to be the brains behind the famous XO sauce. Their secret recipe is a combination of dried shrimp, dried scallops, garlic and chilli. 
Standout dishes include pan-fried garoupa fillet with supreme soy and the steamed Sicilian shrimp and minced pork dumpling. Neil Perry in the Spring Moon kitchen famous for its legendary dumplings. Source: Supplied 
Seventh Son 
Steeped in tradition with recipes handed down from generations, Seventh Son is famous for its barbecued whole suckling pig. Served splayed on all fours, the pig is delicately carved up in traditional Cantonese style. Other classics include salt-baked chicken and winter melon soup. The famous Seventh Son barbecue suckling pig. Source: Supplied
